questions.text: Which of the following is NOT one of the major criteria included in the CASPAR (Classification Criteria for Psoriatic Arthritis) for diagnosing psoriatic arthritis in patients with psoriasis?

options.label: A
options.text: Evidence of psoriasis (current history, or family history)

questions.explanation:
Criteria

Points

Current Psoriasis

2

History of psoriasis

1

Psoriasis in a first or second‐degree relative.

1

Typical psoriatic nail involvement.

1

A negative test for rheumatoid factor.

1

Current dactylitis.

1

History of dactylitis.

1

Radiological evidence of juxta‐articular new bone formation.

1

questions.text: A 12y/o girl comes to the OPD with her parents complaining of multiple small, erythematous, scaly plaques on the trunk with a characteristic raindrop appearance 10 days after a streptococcal throat infection. An image of her lesions is given below. What is the appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Age group

Common in children and young adults

Trigger

Post-streptococcal pharyngitis (esp. Streptococcus pyogenes)

Lesion morphology

Multiple, small (<1 cm), erythematous, scaly plaques ("drop-like")

Distribution

Trunk, proximal limbs

Course

May resolve spontaneously or evolve into chronic plaque psoriasis

questions.text: An orthopaedic surgeon shows you an X-ray of HLA B-27 positive female with seronegative arthritis and psoriatic skin lesions, and you observe the following deformity. What is the eponym given to this deformity?

A 10 year old boy presents to you with scaly, red follicular plaques over his body. He also has areas near his axilla that are spared from these lesions . What is the most likely histopathological pattern that is characteristic of his disease?

options.label: C
options.text: Checkerboard pattern with alternate areas of hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis

questions.correct_answer: C. Checkerboard pattern with alternate areas of hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis

questions.text: A 24 year old girl with psoriatic skin lesions comes to the dermatology OPD with complaints of joint pain and worsening of her skin lesions. You want to use a single agent for managing both her skin disease and arthritis. Which of the following would you use?
Which of the following medications would not be used for treating a patient with moderate to severe psoriasis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Topical Corticosteroids

Vitamin D analogues (Option B)

Tazarotene (Option C)

Coal tar

Mechanism of Action

Local anti-inflammatory action
  • Regulate epidermal keratinocyte proliferation.
  • Regulate immune cell function.

Modulating keratinocyte differentiation and proliferation.
  • Anti-inflammatory
  • Antiproliferative

Frequency

Once daily

Once or twice daily

    

Side Effects
  • Cutaneous atrophy
  • Tachyphylaxis
  • Rebound flare
  • Systemic absorption
  • Local irritation
  • Erythema
  • Scaling.
  • Odor
  • Staining properties
  • Inconvenience of application

questions.text: Which of the following spectrums of UV Light is most commonly used in the treatment of psoriasis?

You are called by an ObGyn resident for the referral of care of a G2P1 woman with a known history of psoriasis, currently in her 2nd trimester. She is complaining of fever and malaise, and examination shows the following findings: What could be a possible fetal complication in this patient?

A patient with a fever of 103°C and pain all over his body comes to your clinic. He recently went to a high-profile medical spa, where he was treated with oral medication for his chronic psoriasis. He was elated with the complete resolution during treatment but woke up with a fever, malaise, and pain three days ago. Skin examination is given in the image below. What is your diagnosis?

A 20 year old male patient comes to your dermatology OPD complaining of non-itchy lesions on the back of his elbows, shins, and knees. On examination, you find scaly lesions that exhibit the Auspitz sign, as shown in the image below. Which of the following processes is responsible for this patient's lesions?
questions.explanation:
Immune cells

Immunomodulators

Examples

Th2 response (Option B)
  • T helper 2 (Th2) cells
  • Eosinophils
  • Mast cells
  • IL-4
  • IL-13

Atopic dermatitis (eczema)

IgE response (Option C)

 
  • B cells (producing IgE antibodies)
  • Mast cells
  • IL-10

Allergic contact dermatitis

Mast cell activation (Option D)
  • Mast cells
  • IL-10

Urticaria (hives)

questions.text: A 24 year old male patient presents to you with joint pain in his fingers. He is currently a fashion student at NIFT and shares that other students bully him for having a few ‘sausage fingers.’ What type of arthritis would you most suspect in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Clinical pattern of presentation

Percentage of patients

Asymmetrical oligoarthritis

50%

Symmetrical polyarthritis

40%

Distal interphalangeal arthritis

5%

Arthritis mutilans

5%

Spinal column or axial involvement

40%

questions.text: On examination of a specific finding in the nail, a dermatology professor confirms the presence of nail psoriasis. Which of these findings helped the professor establish this diagnosis?

During your infectious disease rotation, you examine a 37 year old diabetic female with non-itchy lesions under both her breasts in the ward. The patient mentions that her lesions are non-itchy and exacerbate during the winter. They are salmon in colour, as shown in the image below. What is your next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Characteristics

Flexural Psoriasis

Candidal Intertrigo

 

Image

 

 

 

Colour

Salmon

Red, erythematous

Symmetry

Bilaterally symmetrical
  • Asymmetrical 
  • Satellite lesions are seen

Symptoms

Not pruritic

Pruritic

Exacerbation

Cold environment

Warm, humid environment

Treatment

Topical corticosteroids and emollients

Topical and oral antifungals

questions.text: An immigrant laborer comes to your Sunday volunteer clinic complaining of thickening of the skin on his scalp. The lesions are not itchy, cross the hairline, and are not associated with loss of hair as shown in the given image. What is your diagnosis?

During Dermatology grand rounds, a professor asks you to demonstrate the signs observed in patients with psoriasis. What is the order in which you will see these signs while scraping the lesion with the blunt end of a glass slide?

options.label: A
options.text: Grattage sign, Berkeley’s Membrane, Auspitz Sign

options.label: B
options.text: Auspitz Sign, Berkeley’s Membrane, Grattage Sign

options.label: C
options.text: Berkeley’s Membrane, Grattage Sign, Auspitz Sign

options.label: D
options.text: Berkeley’s Membrane, Auspitz Sign, Grattage Sign

questions.correct_answer: A. Grattage sign, Berkeley’s Membrane, Auspitz Sign

questions.text: While examining a patient with bilaterally symmetrical, silver-white scaly lesions during your Internal Medicine practical exam, you notice that each lesion is surrounded by an area of circumferential pallor as shown in the image below. What is this sign called?

While demonstrating the Koebner phenomenon as depicted in the image below to a group of medical students, a dermatology professor explains the pseudo-Koebner phenomenon as well. Which of the following is a disease that exhibits the pseudo-Koebner phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
Category

Cause

Examples

Images

Category 1 (True koebnerization)

Development of lesions at sites of trauma.
  • Psoriasis
  • Lichen planus (Option A)
  • Vitiligo

Psoriasis

 

Category 2 (Pseudo koebnerization)

Non-immunological and occurs due to auto-inoculation and not trauma.
  • Verruca vulgaris (warts)
  • Molluscum

Warts

 

Category 3 (Occasional koebnerization)

The phenomenon is infrequent or occurs only in specific circumstances.
  • Darier disease
  • Erythema multiforme (Option D).

Erythema multiforme

 

Category 4 (Dubious association with trauma)

Limited evidence or conflicting reports regarding the role of trauma in lesion formation.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris (Option B)
  • Lupus erythematosus

Pemphigus vulgaris

questions.text: As a pathologist in a prestigious private clinic, a physician contacts you for urgent feedback on a skin biopsy from a prominent politician. Suspecting psoriasis, what histopathological findings in the stratum corneum would you communicate to the attending physician?
questions.explanation:
Layer

Findings

Image

Stratum Corneum
  • Hyperkeratosis (increased thickening of stratum corneum)
  • Parakeratosis (retention of nuclei in stratum corneum)
  • Munro's microabscess (collection of neutrophils

Stratum Granulosum
  • Agranulocytosis/ Agranulosis (absent granular layer)

Malpighian layer (Stratum

Spinosum and Basale)
  • Acanthosis (increased thickness) of stratum spinosum
  • Kogoj's Spongiform pustules (collection of neutrophils)

Rete ridges
  • They are elongated and club-shaped (Camel foot appearance).

 

Dermis
  • Suprapapillary thinning is seen as the first histopathological sign.
  • Dilated tortuous blood vessels.
  • Inflammation
